data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/a9ba0e6/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2012x1129+0+150/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F97%2Fdc%2Fce88e478467f912d949a940487b3%2Fscreenshot-2026-02-23-at-11-22-42-am.png" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Among the recent campaign contributions to Illinois Secretary of State Alexi Giannoulias from Perry Mandera and businesses affiliated with him." srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/a9ba0e6/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2012x1129+0+150/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F97%2Fdc%2Fce88e478467f912d949a940487b3%2Fscreenshot-2026-02-23-at-11-22-42-am.png 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/29dc857/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2012x1129+0+150/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F97%2Fdc%2Fce88e478467f912d949a940487b3%2Fscreenshot-2026-02-23-at-11-22-42-am.png 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/a9ba0e6/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2012x1129+0+150/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F97%2Fdc%2Fce88e478467f912d949a940487b3%2Fscreenshot-2026-02-23-at-11-22-42-am.png" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Among the recent campaign contributions to Illinois Secretary of State Alexi Giannoulias from Perry Mandera and businesses affiliated with him.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Illinois State Board of Elections</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Mandera’s Custom Companies has also contributed money to a trade group representing the trucking industry that in turn has given campaign money to Giannoulias, whose agency licenses and regulates truckers in Illinois. The group previously gave to White’s campaign.</p><p>Mandera’s business portfolio has also included an interest in legalized marijuana, starting with medical weed and <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/cannabis/2019/12/3/20994147/perry-mandera-herbal-care-center-marijuana-recreational-weed-license" target="_blank" >eventually getting into recreational sales</a>.</p><p>Mandera and individuals and businesses affiliated with him have been prolific campaign givers over the years to a variety of other candidates and causes, from President Donald Trump, a Republican, to outgoing U.S. Rep. Jesus “Chuy” Garcia, an Illinois Democrat. Custom Companies gave more than $600,000 over the years to state and local campaigns, records show.</p><p>Mandera also has been a donor to charities that have included Loyola Academy, a Catholic high school in Wilmette.</p><p>Two decades ago while Giannoulias was running for Illinois treasurer, questions emerged about loans made by his family’s business, the now-shuttered Broadway Bank where he worked, to reputed crime figures.</p><p>Giannoulias initially defended one of the loans and the borrower — reputed mob figure Michael “Jaws” Giorango — in an interview with the Chicago Tribune. He later walked that back, telling the Chicago Sun-Times: “I should have taken more time to look at their background.”</p><p>"While we did our job as bankers to make sure that they were creditworthy borrowers and the value of the collateral was adequate, I probably should have looked into it more."</p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/the-watchdogs/2026/01/29/lobbyist-john-kelly-possible-chicago-mayor-bid-brandon-johnson-ballys-white-sox-katten-muchin-election" target="_blank" >Veteran lobbyist with clients who regularly intersect with City Hall weighs run for Chicago mayor</a> </li> </ul> </div> <div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/the-watchdogs/2024/07/19/dupage-county-states-attorney-bob-berlin-campaign-fundraiser-donation-palumbo-john-kelly" target="_blank" >Banned contractors participate in campaign fundraiser for DuPage County state’s attorney</a> </li> </ul> </div> <div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/the-watchdogs/2026/01/16/suburban-strip-club-blackjacks-gentlemens-club-south-elgin-kane-county-liquor-commission-video-gambling" target="_blank" >Suburban strip club with sordid past wins back liquor license over objections by some locals</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p></p>
entries.author: Robert Herguth

entries.title: Mom says she killed in self-defense. Will jury agree?
entries.summary: <h3>Good morning, Chicago. ✶</h3><p>🔎 <b>Below</b>: Keshia Golden says she fatally stabbed Calvin Sidney in 2022 when he attacked her after their baby shower. The mother of a 3-year-old still faces murder charges in a case her lawyers argue is self-defense.</p><p>🗞️ <b>Plus</b>: Reflecting on four years after Russia invaded Ukraine, a major campaign donor has reputed mob ties and more news you need to know.</p><p>📧 <b>Subscribe</b>: <a class="Link" href="https://newsletter-hub.suntimes.com/" target="_blank" >Get this newsletter delivered to your inbox weekday mornings.</a></p><p>⏱️: <i>An 8-minute read</i></p><hr><p></p><h4>TODAY’S WEATHER 🌥️</h4><p>Mostly cloudy with a chance of rain and a high near 41.</p><hr><p></p><h4>TODAY’S TOP STORY " srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/e8b145e/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+0/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fb3%2Feb%2Fb72cc9c64fc3b2b761c9a53d1bf2%2Fdomestickilling-260224-12.JPG 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/f92fe95/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+0/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fb3%2Feb%2Fb72cc9c64fc3b2b761c9a53d1bf2%2Fdomestickilling-260224-12.JPG 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/e8b145e/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6122x3436+0+0/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fb3%2Feb%2Fb72cc9c64fc3b2b761c9a53d1bf2%2Fdomestickilling-260224-12.JPG" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Keshia Golden is claiming self-defense in the 2022 killing of her child’s father, Calvin Sidney.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Anthony Vazquez/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p></p><h3><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjitg-l-t/" target="_blank" >Woman says she killed abusive boyfriend to save herself and their unborn child — will jury agree?</a></h3><p></p><h5>By <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjitg-l-i/" target="_blank" >Sophie Sherry</a></h5><p><b>Fatal stabbing</b>: Three and a half years ago, Keshia Golden thought her life was over — one way or another. Golden said that when her boyfriend threw her against a counter, she thought she and her unborn child were going to die. Then, after she fought back and fatally stabbed him, she thought she would spend the rest of her life behind bars, she said. </p><p><b>Her release</b>: Golden was eventually released from jail, thanks to a team of advocates and lawyers who rallied around her. She was able to give birth and raise her daughter on the outside. It has been "the best thing that ever happened" to her, Golden told the Sun-Times.</p><p><b>Pending trial</b>: Now she’s preparing for trial and is fearful that a jury won’t see her side of the story. Golden is due back in court next week. Her lawyers plan to argue she was acting in self-defense against a man with a history of abuse. But they’re pleading for the Cook County state’s attorney’s office to drop the case altogether.</p><p><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjitg-l-d/" target="_blank" ><b>READ MORE</b></a></p><hr><p></p><h4>WAR IN UKRAINE 🇺🇦</h4><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-d00000" name="image-d00000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/e15a9e5/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3000x1684+0+158/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fae%2F48%2Fe046a09a4b7889543bc3be8da186%2Fukraineanniversary-260224-2.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/47784b9/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3000x1684+0+158/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fae%2F48%2Fe046a09a4b7889543bc3be8da186%2Fukraineanniversary-260224-2.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/a346352/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3000x1684+0+158/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fae%2F48%2Fe046a09a4b7889543bc3be8da186%2Fukraineanniversary-260224-2.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Oksana Koledova, owner of a Ukrainian grocery store called Varenychok located at 4840 N. href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjitg-l-h/" target="_blank" >4 years after Russian invasion of Ukraine, area residents reflect</a></h3><p></p><h5>By <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjitg-l-k/" target="_blank" >Violet Miller</a> and <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjitg-l-u/" target="_blank" >Stephanie Zimmermann</a></h5><p><b>'Daily life'</b>: When Russia first invaded Ukraine in 2022, Oksana Koledova regularly checked in with her brother, who was fighting on the front lines, and with loved ones facing down bullets and bombs. Wounded two years ago, her brother now brings resources to fellow troops, and her father runs meals and supplies to soldiers. For Koledova, a Vernon Hills resident who moved to the U.S. 19 years ago, the fight for her home country is her "daily life."</p><p><b>Incalculable toll</b>: An estimated 1.8 million soldiers reportedly have been killed, wounded or gone missing on both sides. But that doesn’t include many who have returned from the battlefield with mental health struggles, Koledova said.</p><p><b>Seeking refuge</b>: Iryna Potishma is among some of the 5.9 million refugees who have fled the country as Russia continues to occupy Ukrainian territory. More than 40,000 Ukrainians have found new homes in the Chicago area. Potishma's loved ones back home have mostly been spared from the battle, though months ago, missiles struck a building near her brother’s apartment. Adapting to life in the U.S. has been her own struggle.</p><p><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjitg-l-o/" target="_blank" ><b>READ target="_blank" >Ex-strip club owner with reputed mob ties is big campaign donor to Alexi Giannoulias</a></h3><p></p><h5>By <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjitg-l-n/" target="_blank" >Robert Herguth</a></h5><p><b>Donor history</b>: For years, businessman Perry Mandera ran a topless bar on the Near North Side, at times with help from reputed organized crime associates, including the late "mob cop" Fred Pascente. These days, Mandera, his family and their businesses are contributing heavily to the campaign fund benefitting Illinois Secretary of State Alexi Giannoulias.</p><p><b>The haul</b>: With Giannoulias a potential candidate for Chicago mayor, companies affiliated with Mandera have contributed at least $80,000 to Citizens for Giannoulias since 2022. That’s the year Giannoulias won his current elected post. Beyond that, Mandera and his family have collectively given nearly $30,000 more over the last five years.</p><p><b>Key context</b>: Pascente, a former Chicago cop known to associate with the late mobster Anthony Spilotro, was listed in a 1997 Chicago Crime Commission report as a known member or associate of organized crime. Pascente died in 2014, not long before his autobiography was released. Titled "Mob Cop: My Life of Crime in the Chicago Police Department," the book includes passages about Mandera.</p><p><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjitg-l-p/" Demolition is expected to take four to six weeks, the university said.</p><p><b>Key context</b>: Constructed in 1926 by architect R. Bernard Kurzon, the 30-unit apartment building at 1224 W. Loyola Ave. was once home to businesses Archie’s Cafe, Roman Susan Gallery and Edge Art. It’s next to the Loyola Red Line stop.</p><p><b>What's next</b>: A spokesperson for Loyola has said the location is part of a future Chicago Transit Authority project, "meaning Loyola will not be the sole decisionmaker regarding its long-term use. href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjitg-l-jy/" target="_blank" >Chris Casacchia</a></h5><p><b>Big bill</b>: The passage of President Donald Trump’s massive tax and spending bill last year carries vast implications for Illinois taxpayers, with experts saying the wealthiest filers are likely to reap the most benefits.</p><p><b>Key context</b>: The so-called One Big Beautiful Bill Act was signed into law July 2025 and made permanent several provisions in Trump’s old Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, which expired Dec. 31, 2025.</p><p><b>Overview</b>: The bill includes more than just tax cuts. It makes spending cuts to certain federal programs as well as boosts spending for some agencies. Overall, the megabill will upend household finances, but will also provide more clarity for financial planning, financial advisers have said.</p><p><b>Down to brass tax</b>: Find our breakdown of the bill's vast implications for Illinois taxpayers <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjitg-l-jj/" target="_blank" >here</a>.</p><p><b>From our tax guide</b>: <br></p><ul class="rte2-style-ul" style="line-height: inherit; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px; margin-left: 24px; padding: 0px; list-style-type: disc;" id="rte-742dbe73-118a-11f1-9503-0dbc8aae0681"><li><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjitg-l-jt/" target="_blank" >What taxpayers need to know about savings plans, tax changes in 2026</a></li><li><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjitg-l-ji/" target="_blank" >Strategies to consider if you’re looking to reduce capital gains taxes</a></li><li><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjitg-l-jd/" target="_blank" >How to avoid underpayment penalties by the IRS</a></li></ul><p><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjitg-l-jh/" target="_blank" ><b>MORE ON TAXES</b></a></p><hr><p></p><h4> FROM THE PRESS BOX 🏈🏒🏀</h4><ul class="rte2-style-ul" style="line-height: inherit; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px; margin-left: 24px; padding: 0px; list-style-type: disc;" id="rte-742de580-118a-11f1-9503-0dbc8aae0681"><li><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjitg-l-jk/" target="_blank" ><b>NFL Scouting Combine</b></a>: Bears coach Ben Johnson and general manager Ryan Poles will meet the media Tuesday blocks from the Indiana statehouse. Billy Meilicke and his crew.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Pat Nabong/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p></p><h3><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjitg-l-ti/" target="_blank" >Icebreaker boat the James J. Versluis has been shattering lake since 1957</a></h3><h3></h3><h5>Reporting by <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjitg-l-td/" target="_blank" >Stefano Esposito</a></h5><p>Before boarding the almost 70-year-old James J. Versluis, passengers get a life jacket and a set of ear plugs, because things can get "loud and crunchy."</p><p>As the Versluis sets off from its mooring at Navy Pier one morning in early February, the sound of its 126-ton steel hull shuddering through ice grates on the ear like a trash compactor chomping rocks.</p><p>"For the first couple of years, when you’re smacking up against ice, it’s really nerve-racking. You just feel like that ice is going to pop right through the hull," said Eddie Popelas, who served as the tugboat’s engineer from 2002 to 2013 and whose father was at one time the boat’s captain.</p><p>For Capt. Billy Meilicke and Marine Engineer Rich Frizelis — in charge of the tugboat on this morning — the noise is just part of the daily soundtrack that includes the thrum of the 850-horsepower diesel engine and the single blast of the foghorn.</p><p><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjjitg-l-th/" target="_blank" ><b>READ MORE</b></a></p><hr><p></p><h4>WATCH: ABOARD AN ICE
